Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with lion walking to right and turning head to look backwards, with a long tail raised and sun-disc above back; motif possibly stamped rather than incised; pierced through diameter; glazed surface surviving as thin greenish layer in some parts; yellowish core, with porous, rough texture; much worn surface.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Nicholson Museum, University of Sydney. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Scarabs and scaraboids with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 34-45, see especially no. 35 for this piece though lion looking forward not backwards). This scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, see subtype A73-88 for scarabs with similar motif).
